item.title: Version 3.5.1; Universal Version / TVDB patch
item.description:
Release 3.5.1 (Universal version)

  • Apple Silicon support (universal, so unfortunately twice the size)
  • Fixes crash that can occur if TVDB sends invalid data
  • Blue icons instead of Yellow to match newer TiVo style; still uses ! to indicate potential imminent deletion.
  • Warning: TiVo RPC certificate will expire December 2022

Fixes:

  • Better test for Java presence for TiVoLibre.
  • Folder with any recordings in progress now shows recording icon to match TiVo's style.

item.title: Version 3.4.3; New TiVo certificate
item.description:
Release 3.4.3 (New TiVo certificate)

  • New TiVo certificate (old one expired December 2020)
  • Big Sur compatibility
  • Upgraded Handbrake CLI
  • Migration to Firebase
  • Note: incompatible with macOS 10.9 or 10.10

Fixes:

  • Improved reliability for finding TiVos on Catalina.
  • Misc minor fixes.

item.title: Version 3.4.1; Final for macOS 10.10
item.description:
Release 3.4.1

This is final release for macOS 10.9 or 10.10

  • New Get Info command for TiVos (disk space, network connectivity etc) in Edit Tivos and Remote Control

Fixes:

  • Improved reliability for finding completed videos on disk.
  • Help files look better in Dark mode.
  • Better logging to diagnose occasional delays in SkipMode.
  • Misc minor fixes.

item.title: Version 2.5.1; H.264 and other major improvements
item.description:
Release 2.5.1 - 10.7 and 10.8

This version is only for systems using 10.7 or 10.8 as well as older Macs

Due to the included binaries from other open-source efforts, it’s getting much harder to support these older systems, but given the H.264 conversion, It has the older binaries (such as mencoder, ffmpeg, ccextractor etc) but otherwise should run fine.

  • H.264 compatibility (new format for cable companies)
  • Autodetects H.264 transition by channel
  • Redesigned Formats (simpler, more compatible)
  • New Channels preference screen
  • Better handling for AC3 5.1 audio
  • Many bug fixes

MPEG-4 Transition

Comcast and other cable companies are migrating from MPEG-2 compressed streams to MPEG-4 (aka H.264). They do this to reduce the size and improve the quality of their signals. Comcast seem to be rolling this out slowly, one market at a time and changing over one channel at a time. Although this transition requires many changes to cTiVo, they are transparent in normal operation, except that older Formats may be incompatible. With this release, we’ve provided a whole new set of Formats, and taken the opportunity to make the Format selection process easier.

See cTiVo Home for more information.
